items.content_html:
I was planning to release a short story collection on Kindle, but now I’m thinking about putting it together in iA writer and releasing it as an EPUB.

I don’t have much of a digital presence and I’m not going to put a marketing strategy behind it. The real value will come from the experience of putting the collection together. And if some people read it and I get some exposure, that’ll be pure bonus.
items.content_text:
I was planning to release a short story collection on Kindle, but now I'm thinking about putting it together in iA writer and releasing it as an EPUB.

items.content_html: Someone recently shared a story about how he had to dodge the clothesline whenever he backed out to leave his grandmother’s house and then when he went back to her place after she’d died, he accommodated for the clothesline even though it was no longer there.
items.content_text: Someone recently shared a story about how he had to dodge the clothesline whenever he backed out to leave his grandmother's house and then when he went back to her place after she'd died, he accommodated for the clothesline even though it was no longer there.

items.content_html: I was thinking about those tales of the old days, when strangers would drop in and say something like, “We’re headed out Californy way. Do you have a spare room?” and the homeowner thought nothing of it and accomodated. Then I realized Airbnb ain’t nothing new.
items.content_text: I was thinking about those tales of the old days, when strangers would drop in and say something like, "We're headed out Californy way. Do you have a spare room?" and the homeowner thought nothing of it and accomodated. Then I realized Airbnb ain't nothing new.

items.content_html:
I’ve been in a writing funk lately. This morning I forced myself to resume a certain short story, which took a slight turn and excited me and now has the writer wheels in my brain turning again.

I’m sure there’s a moral somewhere in this anecdote.
items.content_text:

I'm sure there's a moral somewhere in this anecdote.

items.content_html: WandaVision started off great. The show did so much right, especially the exploration of loss and grief, but it really crapped itself at the end.

items.content_html:
A couple years ago, my son picked up this bookmark and said, “It’s you, Daddy,” alerting me that I am literally his model for what it means to be a man.

No pressure, son. No pressure.

items.content_html:
Our last visit to Fry’s, in January 2020. I had never before been sad to see a store withering away.

I wasted so much money here and bought my son so many 50-cent ninja men from the gumball-style machines at the front of the store.

RIP in peace, Fry’s
items.content_text: Our last visit to Fry's, in January 2020. I had never before been sad to see a store withering away. I wasted so much money here and [bought my son so many 50-cent ninja men from the gumball-style machines](https://jakelacaze.com/2020/01/18/bye-bye-miss.html) at the front of the store. [RIP in peace](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/frys-electronics-chain-closing/), Fry's

items.content_html: Reading Ernest Hemingway’s In Our Time makes me realize that I don’t dislike Hemingway–I dislike Hemingway’s novels. His short stories are top notch.
items.content_text: Reading Ernest Hemingway's *In Our Time* makes me realize that I don't dislike Hemingway--I dislike Hemingway's novels. His short stories are top notch.

items.content_html:
2 takeaways from 2020 and beyond:

  1. When criticizing a system, don’t compare it to Utopia. Compare it to absolute disaster, since that is far likelier than Utopia.

  2. Functioning systems are not a given; they are blessings which can be easily derailed.
items.content_text:
2 takeaways from 2020 and beyond:

1. When criticizing a system, don't compare it to Utopia. Compare it to absolute disaster, since that is far likelier than Utopia.

2. Functioning systems are not a given; they are blessings which can be easily derailed.

items.content_html: Today I’m thinking about the time a group of us were at Cafe Brazil and the waiter said, “Happy Valentine’s Day, y’all,” as he dropped off the check and turned to walk away and it was such a strange encounter.

items.content_html:
Journaling doesn’t work for me; it ends up a mundane retelling of the day’s events with no flavor.

For last night’s entry, I took a real event from the day and fictionalized it a bit for a vignette/short story. I might have found a new journaling practice.

Journaling doesn't work for me; it ends up a mundane retelling of the day's events with no flavor.

For last night's entry, I took a real event from the day and fictionalized it a bit for a vignette/short story. I might have found a new journaling practice.

items.content_html: Last night I prepped the John Wick trilogy for my Plex server, and now I’m itching to rewatch the original. I love the simplicity of John Wick and how the movie knows what it is and stays in its lane.

items.content_html: A few years ago, I deleted my Facebook account when I realized that I was hiding updates from about half of my “friends”. LinkedIn is feeling reminiscent of that experience.

items.content_html:
Going through the Micro Monday archives, I recently listened to #83, in which @jeremycherfas and @jean discuss Italian food, which inspired me to make stuffed shells tonight.

So my wife now approves of micro.blog even though she doesn’t really know what it is.
items.content_text:
Going through the Micro Monday archives, I recently listened to #83, in which [@jeremycherfas](https://micro.blog/jeremycherfas) and [@jean](https://micro.blog/jean) [discuss Italian food](https://monday.micro.blog/2020/03/30/jeremy-cherfas-aka.html), which inspired me to make stuffed shells tonight. 

So my wife now approves of micro.blog even though she doesn't really know what it is.

items.content_html: One of the most refreshing things about micro.blog: I haven’t seen any gifs or memes. Not that I’m against them completely, but after a few weeks on micro.blog, it’s obvious just how prevalent memes and gifs are on social media in general.

items.content_html:
Confession: I once wrote an instruction manual for using a chimney starter for a technical writing class, but I almost always have problems starting my fire with a chimney starter.

I am a fraud.
items.content_text:
Confession: I once wrote [an instruction manual for using a chimney starter](https://jakelacaze.com/uploads/2021/c4b7cb86bd.pdf) for a technical writing class, but I almost always have problems starting my fire with a chimney starter. 

I am a fraud.

items.title: Giving micro.blog a shot
items.content_html: Who knows how long I’ll stick around with micro.blog. I have a habit of moving my site from host to host lately. But so far I like what I see, so it’s worth a shot.
items.content_text:
Who knows how long I'll stick around with micro.blog. I have a habit of moving my site from host to host lately. But so far I like what I see, so it's worth a shot.

items.content_html:
I recently learned “The Animal Farm Principle” for productivity:

All hours are equal, but some hours are more equal than others.
items.content_text:
I recently learned "The Animal Farm Principle" for productivity:

> All hours are equal, but some hours are more equal than others.

items.title: Every Day is Significant
items.content_html: Every day is significant. No day is more special than any other because every day is one that will never repeat.

(For the record, I love me some em dashes.)

items.title: What have we learned from 2020?
items.content_html:
2020 was not a great year. But it was a year. It happened. So let’s see what we can learn from it.

P. S. I apologize that the audio is so quiet. Learning pains, ya know…
